Award.AwardTitle: A Non-Archimedean Approach to the Geometry of General Curves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic geometry, which studies solutions to systems of polynomial equations, is a central topic in mathematics with applications to many other disciplines. Many natural phenomena of interest in physics, biology, and computer science can be modeled by polynomials, making algebraic geometry a useful tool for the scientific community at large. This research project aims to study the geometric properties of the simplest objects in algebraic geometry, known as algebraic curves. While some curves may have exotic or pathological properties, it is expected that most curves do not. This goal of this project is to show that "typical" curves are geometrically well-behaved, using techniques from the recently developed field of non-Archimedean analytic geometry.

Brill-Noether theory aims to study the geometry of a curve by examining all of its maps to projective space, or equivalently the existence and behavior of its linear series. A major change in perspective occurred during the twentieth century, as the field shifted from studying fixed to general curves -- that is, general points in the moduli space of curves. A standard approach to the study of general curves is via degeneration arguments. One considers a family of smooth curves degenerating to a singular curve, and attempts to deduce geometric properties of the general fiber using information about the singular fiber. Recently, it has been observed that this theory fits within a broader framework of non-Archimedean analytic techniques. This project focuses on outstanding problems concerning the Brill-Noether theory of general curves, and how new techniques in non-Archimedean analytic geometry may shed light on these problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Results from this grant include 11 research papers, 4 of which are published.  These papers cover a wide range of topics, including Hurwitz-Brill-Noether theory, graph invariants inspired by the geometry of curves, work on the Strong Maximal Rank Conjecture with applications to moduli of curves, zeta functions of matroids, and tropical Prym varieties.

Funds from this grant have been used to support undergraduate research at the University of Kentucky, primarily through the UK Math Lab. The PI has been heavily involved in undergraduate research throughout his career, having supervised 21 undergraduates and 1 high school student in 10 separate research projects.  Six of these projects were here at the University of Kentucky during the period of grant support.  Of these students, 5 are women, including one trans woman, and one is a first generation college student. Two of the projects at UK have resulted in short papers that have been submitted to peer-reviewed journals.

 

In addition to promoting undergraduate research, the Math Lab also serves as a recruiting tool and facilitator of student engagement. One of the features that sets the UK Math Lab apart from other math labs is the weekly activity constructing mathematical quilts. The quilting activity is low commitment, and has been remarkably successful in improving the lab's demographics, recruiting students who may be intimidated by the more intensive research projects or who may not recognize their own mathematical inclinations. The current project is to quilt a Cayley table for the symmetric group on 4 letters, with shading indicating its composition series. Previous quilts constructed in the UK Math Lab have been exhibited at the Art Exhibit at the Joint Meetings.

 

Over the period of NSF support, the PI has supervised 4 PhD students and one postdoc. One of these students has recently graduated, accepting a postdoctoral position at Colorado School of Mines this past Spring. Of the 4 students, two are women, one is a person of color, and the fourth is a first-generation college student who dropped out of high school and earned his GED in prison.

 

During the period of NSF support, the PI has organized two conferences and one MSRI summer school. One of these conferences was a workshop at AIM, and the other a week-long conference at BIRS-CMO. The PI has also written two pieces for the Notices of the AMS. One of these, written for the Early Career section, is a description of the atmosphere at large public research institutions like the University of Kentucky, in comparison to other types of academic jobs. The other, which has yet to appear, is a short expository note on the chip-firing game and its connections to algebraic geometry.
